Title: Linking forum posts - HowThingsWork-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Hi, could anyone please help me with understanding what does work mean? Work=Force*Distance, but I'm not sure I understand the distance aspect. Is it the distance the object does actually move in reality, or is it the distance the object WOULD move if there wasn't any air, friction or other factors? I mean, for example, you can push an object on a smooth surface with 1 newton force and it will move for, let's say, 30 cm and you can push the same object on rough terrain with the same 1 newton force and it will move only 5 cm. So the amount of work for the smooth surface will be more than for the rough terrain?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The work you do on any object is the force you exert on that object times the distance that object moves in the direction of your force on it. Nothing else matters -- not friction, air resistance, or anything else. If you do work on the object according to that rule, then you are definitely transferring energy to the object. If there are other forces acting on the object, then they may also be doing work (or negative work) on the object. For example, if you are pushing a desk across the floor, you are doing work on it according to the rule: your work is equal to the force you exert on the desk times the distance the desk moves in the direction of your force on the desk. But the floor is exerting a frictional force on the desk's legs and the desk is moving a distance in the direction opposite to the floor's force on the desk. As a result, the floor is doing negative work on the desk! So you are transferring energy to the desk and the floor is removing that energy from the desk (by way of friction). The missing energy -- the energy removed from the desk by friction -- ends up as thermal energy in the floor surface and bottom of the legs. Lou

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
To answer this question, let's take a detailed look at what is exerting a torque on what. Suppose we have a boy and a girl riding on a seesaw. We will assume that the center of rotation is the seesaw's pivot, so all the torques will be defined as around that point. I'll list all the torques that the four objects in the story exert directly on one another (or 'produce' by way of a force). It's actually a long list: [Note: The four objects are the boy, the girl, the seesaw, and the Earth (which includes the ground on which the seesaw is mounted).] 1. gravity exerts a torque on the boy (around the seesaw's pivot) 2. gravity exerts a torque on the girl 3. gravity exerts a torque on the seesaw itself, but only if that seesaw is not balance properly 4-6. gravity exerts a torque on the Earth due to the boy, girl, and seesaw respectively (the Newton's third law pairs of 1, 2, and 3) 7. the boy exerts a torque on the seesaw 8. the seesaw exerts a torque on the boy 9. the girl exerts a torque on the seesaw 10. the seesaw exerts a torque on the girl 11. The ground's torque on the boy if he touches it 12. The boy's torque on the ground if he touches it. 13. The ground's torque on the girl if she touches it. 14. The girl's torque on the ground if she touches it. 15. The ground's torque on the seesaw if the seesaw touches the ground 16. The seesaw's torque on the ground if the seesaw touches the ground The net torque on the boy is the sum of 1, 8, and 11. The net torque on the girl is the sum of 2, 10, and 13. The net torque on the seesaw is the sum of 3, 7, 9, and 15. The net torque on the earth & ground is the sum of 4, 5, 6, 12, 14, 16 Each object undergoes angular acceleration in response to the net force acting on it. Because of their contact to one another, the various objects tend to move together -- which means that the torques they exert on one another are strongly influenced by their contact with one another. In other words, the boy undergoes angular accelerate on his own, but the seesaw beneath him is likely to undergo the same angular acceleration because of the torques those two objects exert on one another. My in-video statement 'the boy exerts a torque on the girl' is somewhat misleading. That torque of boy on girl is indirect -- they don't touch and thus can't directly exert torques on one another [neglecting gravity between the boy and girl, which is too weak to notice]. Instead, the boy exerts a torque on the seesaw and the seesaw exerts a torque on the girl. The same with transferring energy -- if the boy is descending and the girl is ascending, then the boy is doing work on the seesaw and the seesaw is doing work on the girl, so energy flows from the boy to the seesaw to the girl. The way I want you to think about the seesaw in that video is as a transfer device -- it is allowing the boy to exert a torque on the girl (albeit indirectly) and it is conveying energy from the boy to the girl (again, indirectly). If the seesaw is motionless, then there is no work being done by anything on anything else -- work requires motion. Lou

Input.threadtitle: When does the seesaw moves as obeying the Newton's First Law of rotation ?
Input.posts:
Below is the Newton's First Law. A rigid object that is not wobbling and that is free of external torques rotates at constant angular velocity. According to this law, when does the seesaw moves in obeying Newton's First Law?
Upvotes:
-1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
When the seesaw has no riders, it is rigid object that is constrained by its pivot so that it cannot wobble. It there moves according to Newton's first law of rotational motion and has a constant angular velocity. When its end touches the ground, however, that end experiences a torque and the seesaw is no longer described by Newton's third law. With riders on it, the seesaw can still obey Newton's third law of rotational motion if those riders position themselves properly (so that they balance the seesaw) and if those riders don't move about (and ruin the rigid character of the seesaw). Lou
